section.title: Installation
section.para: Binary executables are available for three of the most widely used platforms: 32-bit Linux, OSX (Darwin), and Windows. If your platform is not compatible with any of these, you can build the software from the source code.

section.title: Linux
section.para: Running the Linux binary version of PyLith requires a 32-bit compatible machine with GLIBC 2.2 or later.

listitem.para: Unpack the tarball (i.e., tar -zxvf pylith-0.8-linux-x86.tar.gz) in a suitable location.

Add pylith-0.8-linux-x86/bin to your PATH. You will likely want to add something like PATH=${PATH}:replace_with_absolute_path/pylith-0.8-linux-x86/bin to your .bashrc file (if you are using bash as your shell) or the equivalent to your .cshrc file (if you are using tcsh as your shell).

section.title: Windows
section.para: This Windows binary version of PyLith should be compatible with Windows NT, Windows 2000, and Windows XP.

listitem.para: Double click on the setup.exe file you just downloaded and follow the instructions for installing.

section.title: Building the source code
section.para: Building PyLith from the source code is not a trivial task because PyLith depends on several other packages. In general, each package must be compiled from source using binary compatible compilers.

The software must be built starting from the bottom of the dependency list and working upwards. The steps below describe the recommended way to build PyLith and the external packages on which it depends. Some of the dependencies can be satisfied using precompiled binaries (e.g., RedHat and Fink packages). When choosing whether to use a precompiled binary package to satisfy any of the dependencies remember that all of the compilers and settings used in building the code must be compatible.
